results.title: Man of Flowers
results.brief_description: Norman Kaye won the AFI’s best actor award for this stunning portrayal of Charles Bremer, a strange and sensitive man, whose sensual appreciation of all things beautiful led to his bizarre and erotic relationship with a young bi-sexual named Lisa. “Man of Flowers” is both erotic and richly amusing with a tragic after glow.

results.title: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit: Television Production Unit and University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: Bushfires are an inevitable hazard in Australia. The tranquillity of the bush belies its potential to burn fiercely when conditions are suitable. This program shows how bushfires start fires in buildings, how embers, radiation and flame, aided by wind cause ignition and destruction of buildings; that embers are the most important means of ignition; that well-designed buildings have a very good chance of survival; and that such buildings will provide a safer place of refuge for people in bushfires.
results.title_for_label: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival

results.title: Double concerto: a film about the pianist Roger Woodward
results.creator_credit: Hugh Piper, Angela Catterns, Abstract Productions and Endeavour Film Productions
results.brief_description: The star of “Double Concerto” is the brilliant Australian pianist Roger Woodward. His inspiration and fellow musician is the equally brilliant Polish violinist, Wanda Wilkomirska. Together they play the double concerto “Southern Cross”, a concerto written especially for them by Australia’s most internationally acclaimed composer, Barry Conyingham. The film follows Roger and Wanda in rehearsal, in concert and in rambling walks along the sea shores. They discuss their music, their politics and their personal lives.

results.title: Women in the surf
results.brief_description: The first non-fiction feature about Australia’s women of the surf tells the history of women’s surfing in Australia from 1915. It moves through the big board era to the present day, with women becoming a surfing entity in their own right. The video shows the women surf riders surfing their own calender and tells of their hopes, fears and pleasures as they ride the waves.

results.title: Heads 'n' Tails (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jane Oehr, Kay Francis and New South Wales. Dept. of Health
results.brief_description: A program that depicts the inter action between a group of teenagers coping with the pressures of growing up in an urban environment. An educational and entertaining video with a sequel called “On The Loose”.

results.title: Errol Flynn
results.creator_credit: Michael Carson, Pamela Vanneck, Ron Saunders and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
This moving drama series on important figures from Australia’s past brings Australian history to life. Errol Flynn’s natural charm and good looks saw him become a screen legend as Hollywood’s greatest swashbuckling lover and matinee idol. This film takes an irreverent look at the nineteen year old Flynn’s escapades in Sydney as he sets off on the path to notoriety.

results.title: The Esso Australian Jazz Summit
results.brief_description: Sydney’s famous Bondi Beach came alive with a foot-tapping, head-nodding event, the First Australian Jazz Summit. All styles of jazz were represented, from modern, traditional through to avant-garde. Various ensembles and configurations of players performed, from standard groups to Big Bands, feature soloists and, of course, jam sessions and improvisation. Rated: G

results.title: Crossroads Rock Concert
results.creator_credit: Richard Hodder, Salvation Army and Salvation Army. Australia Southern Territory
results.brief_description: Three Christian rock groups gig together in aid of Salvation Army’s Crossroads Program for Homeless Youth, interspersed with modern parables about being young and different from the crowd. “Crossroads” is a video about, and for, contemporary Christian youth.
